The Davis R Users’s Group

Welcome to the Davis R User’s Group (DRUG)! We are a community of R users at UC Davis who support each other in using R for science.

  • Come to our weekly work sessions.
    This is the core purpose of DRUG. We have weekly, 2-hour, work sessions where people bring their computers to work on their own projects, and ask each other questions as needed. There is no instruction and we have no TAs - just mutual support in R, statistics, and related topics.

  • Join the mailing list. The mailing list is an online supplement to our in-person work sessions.

  • Use the Resources Below. We’ve compiled a list of resources to help you get started using R and find answers to your questions.

Some tips on getting started:

  • Download R here
  • After you install R, download and install RStudio. RStudio is a program that makes R easier to use. Importantly, it works across most computer platforms, and has features that make it easy to share your work and collaborate. If you are have done computer programming in other languages and have other preferred ways of working with code it may not be the environment for you, but it is being widely adopted by both beginning and advanced R users.

Resources for R Help

Please Add Additional Resources in the Comments!. I will add them to the page.

  • Google is your first stop. You’ll most likely reach most of the resources below while searching for your specific question.
  • Our regular R work sessions and listserv are great places to ask questions, especially if you are not sure what you are looking

Web Resources

There’s no need to reinvent the wheel. Here are lists of beginner’s resources which others have compiled

  • Rseek is a search engine for R resources.
  • RStudio’s Getting Help with R Page
  • List of Free Online R Tutorials
  • Beginner tips from Revolution Analytics

Books

  • R in a nutshell by Joseph Adler is a good book that’s available in the Davis library and online for Davis users.
  • A Primer of Ecology with R by M. Henry H. Stevens is also available online

Other Mailing Lists

These mailing list are very useful not just as a place to ask questions, but to search for previously asked questions.

  • The R-Help mailing list and it’s many subgroups, including an Ecology-specific group
  • Stack Overflow is a popular Q&A site for computer programming that a lot of discussions about R.
  • The Davis Scientific and Statistical Computing List is mostly used by advanced users and includes some of the developers of R.

R Courses

There are a few courses at UC Davis that use R.

  • Duncan Temple Lang (one of the developers of R) teaches Statistical Computing (STA141), a course mostly about R but also more general topics in computer science for statistics.
  • Richard McElreath’s Statistical Rethinking (ANT298) a course Bayesian statistical methods which doesn’t focus on R but teaches enough for the applications in the course.
  • Marissa Baskett and Sebastian Schreiber teach Computational methods in population biology (ECL298) in alternate years. This course also isn’t explicitly about R but teaches enough basics so as to be able to use it for the applications in the course. They also created this handy cheat sheet
  • XXXXX Provides an optional extra section to learn techniques in R in addition to SAS

Miscellaneous

  • R-bloggers
  • The One R Tip A Day Twitter Account
  • #rstats is a common hashtag for discussing R on Twitter

General Statistics Resources at UC Davis

  • The UC Davis Department of Statistics has a consulting service that is free for disseration-related statistical advice
  • XXXX Teaches a methods course in statistics for ecologists.
